abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts. Despite a satisfactory Bank
            performance, the Borrower performance is rated
            unsatisfactory, thus lessons are addressed in the context of
            interest to the Bank, and to the Borrower. Ensuring
            institutional viability in terms of commitment, and support
            from the government, the council of ministers, and the
            parliament, and, clear agreement on important policy
            dimensions, such as land site acquisition, environmental
            regulations, participation of municipalities, and cost
            recovery, should be agreed, supported by public consensus,
            prior to launching new operations in Lebanon. Unless these
            factors are ensured, this kind of project will not be
            sustainable, even though the technical design is the correct
            one. In particular, social analysis and assessment should be
            undertaken during project preparation, including as
            necessary, conflict-resolution mechanisms, to avoid social
            resistance, while concentrating on fully integrated systems.
            Furthermore, The Bank should proactively take remedial
            measures such as canceling the project when the new
            political leadership does not support it, or if the project
            is encountering serious obstacles in its implementation,
            setting a time limit to either restructure, or cancel a
            project. Lessons for the Borrower, suggest the need for
            strong, proactive local champions, who can facilitate site
            selection, and maintain commitment of all stakeholders,
            including central government, municipalities,
            nongovernmental Organizations, and local community
            residents. This is because given Lebanon's ethnic
            tapestry, a participatory approach to build a consensus in
            the communities, municipalities, and the central government
            is necessary to address key strategic issues within a new
            national solid waste management strategy, that includes land
            site acquisition, environmental regulations, participation
            of municipalities and cost recovery.
